newsitem.title: USA: LOCAL ECONOMY ROBUST IN EARLY Q3 -- RICHMOND FED.
newsitem.headline: LOCAL ECONOMY ROBUST IN EARLY Q3 -- RICHMOND FED.

text.p: Economic activity in the fifth U.S. district appears fairly robust in the early part of the third quarter, with broad-based underlying strength, said an official at the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond.

"As we are beginning the third quarter, at least in our district, we're looking at fairly robust activity. The quarter appears to be getting off on a pretty good foot," Raymond Owens, chief regional economist at the Richmond Fed, told Reuters Financial Television.
Owens spoke to Reuters shortly after the release of the Richmond Fed's monthly manufacturing shipments index, which fell sharply to a negative 10 in July from 15 in June.
Although the headline numbers for the regional manufacturing survey suggested activity deceleration, the Richmond Fed economist said the drop was seasonal.

"What we saw was a very strong rebound in retail. Retail sales ... indicate that there is strength across the board in our district," Owens said. "The turndown in manufacturing is more a seasonal factor than any underlying phenomena."
Owens also said he saw some wage pressures in the region. But he added that upward pressures on prices remained modest.

The Richmond Fed survey cover industries located in the nation's fifth economic distric, which encompasses the District of Columbia, Maryland, North Carolina, South Carolina, Virginia and most of West Virginia.
